Expectation1: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation1: A file for a straightforward procedural hearing scheduled in two weeks has just been delivered to your chambers for preliminary review.
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: Their timely presence is crucial at a high-stakes proceeding that could determine the case outcome
Story: I sat at my desk, the thick envelope of case files freshly delivered, its weight a silent reminder of my duty as a judge. The hearing was two weeks away, but the expectation was clear: I must review every detail, no matter how routine the matter seemed. My eyes skimmed the first page, but my mind kept drifting to the clock. In less than fifteen minutes, I was expected in another courtroom—not as a judge, but as an advocate. My client’s future hinged on my punctual presence; the opposing counsel was notorious for exploiting any delay. I felt the pressure mounting, the judge in me insisting on diligence and preparation, the advocate in me demanding urgency and focus elsewhere. My hands trembled slightly as I tried to read, but the words blurred. I couldn’t ignore either role, yet fulfilling one seemed to betray the other. The minutes ticked by, each one tightening the knot in my chest as I wrestled with the impossible expectations pulling me in opposite directions.
